choices.text: Decreased availability of calcitonin gene related peptide

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not a probable mechanism of development of nitrate tolerance?
questions.solution:
Mechanisms of development of nitrate tolerance:

  1. Decreased tissue sulfhydryl groups
  2. Increased oxygen free radical generation
  3. Decreased availability of calcitonin gene related peptide

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 588

Amyl nitrite is absorbed at a faster rate via inhalation route than p.o route.

Excretion is primarily by way of liver

questions.solution:
1. Partially denitrates metabolites has long half life
  2. Excretion of drugs is primarily by way of kidney
  3. Nitrates administered via sublingual route has good p.o absorption, but high FPM.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 587

questions.text: A 54 yr old complaints of palpitation, weakness and lightheadedness. His ECG reports is attached. Which of the following can be the pharmacological therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Second-degree AV block (Mobitz Type I)- AV conduction time progressively lengthens before a block.

Indications of permanent pacing:

  • Symptomatic brady with any degree of AV block
  • Asymptomatic brady with second-degree Mobitz type II
  • Asymptomatic brady with third-degree AV block.

Pharmacological treatment:

Intravenous atropine → 0.5 mg IV

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 582

questions.text: A 50 yr old diagnosed with hypertension was treated with a cardio selective beta blocker. After 6 months of therapy, the patient complains of giddiness and lightheadedness. His heart rate was 52 bpm and ECG shows first degree AV block. History reveals he was also taking one powder mixed with water daily for controlling his BP which he bought online. What might be the content of that powder?
questions.solution:
Beta blockers should not be given with cardio-selective calcium channel blockers (Verapamil and Diltiazem) which might cause bradycardia, asystole and AV block.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 594

questions.text: This adverse effect associated with use of which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin → Due to high lipid solubility → when given parenterally, might cause distal ischemia causing purple glove syndrome.

ADRs of Phenytoin

Gingival hyperplasia occurs in approximately 20% of all patients. coarsening of facial features.

Hyperglycemia and glycosuria appear to be due to inhibition of insulin secretion.

Osteomalacia, with hypocalcemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase activity, has been attributed to both altered metabolism of vitamin D and the attendant inhibition of intestinal absorption of Ca2+.

Phenytoin also increases the metabolism of vitamin K and reduces the concentration of vitamin K-dependent proteins that are important for normal Ca2+ metabolism in bone.

Hypersensitivity reactions include morbilliform rash in 2% to 5% of patients and occasionally more serious skin reactions, including Stevens- Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

Drug-induced systemic lupus erythematosus, hepatic necrosis, hematological reactions including neutropenia and leukopenia, red cell aplasia, agranulocytosis, and mild thrombocytopenia also have been reported.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 393

questions.text: What is drugs 'A'?
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam→ Blocks Synaptic Vesicular Protein Type 2A (SVP2A), Dose reduced in renal failure

Brivacetam→ Blocks SVP2A and Na+ channels, Dose reduced in liver failure

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 401

questions.text:
Match the adverse effect with the drugs:
1.Lacosamide a.Hyperammonemia
2.Topiramate b.Aplastic anemia
3.Valproate c.Naming difficulty
4.Felbamate d.Suicidality
questions.solution:
ADRs of following anti-epileptics:

Valproate

Asymptomatic rise in serum transaminase is often noted; monitoring of liver function is advised.

A rare but serious adverse effect is fulminant hepatitis; occurs only in children (especially below 3 yr). Those with hepatic disease or who receive other anticonvulsant or hepatotoxic drug are at greater risk.

Lacosamide

Adverse effects are ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, tremor, depression and cardiac arrhythmia.

Topiramate

Adverse effects are impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias and renal stones.

Felbamate - Risk of aplastic anemia and hepatitis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 444-447

questions.text: 43 yr old female, whose BP was 160/100 was on treatment with an ARB and CCB. Due to decreased response, a diuretic was decided to add in the therapy. Long term diuretic therapy acts by which of the following mechanisms in treatment of hypertension?
questions.solution:
The initial action of thiazide diuretics decreases extracellular volume by interacting with a thiazide-sensitive NCC (SLC12A3) expressed in the distal convoluted tubule in the kidney, enhancing Na+ excretion in the urine, and leading to a decrease in cardiac output. However, the hypotensive effect is maintained during long-term therapy due to decreased vascular resistance; cardiac output returns to pretreatment values, and extracellular volume returns to almost normal due to compensatory responses such as activation of the RAS. The explanation for the long-term vasodilation induced by thiazide diuretics is unknown. Hydrochlorothiazide may open Ca2+-activated K+ channels, leading to hyperpolarization of vascular smooth muscle cells, which leads in turn to closing of L-type Ca2+ channels and lower probability of opening, resulting in decreased Ca2+ entry and reduced vasoconstriction. Hydrochlorothiazide also inhibits vascular carbonic anhydrase, which, hypothetically, could alter smooth muscle cell systolic pH and thereby cause opening of Ca2+-activated K+ channels with the consequences noted previously.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 606

questions.text: A 45 yr old female on prescription of an anti-HT drug, gradually started to develop joint pain, muscle pain and fever. There was associated photosensitivity and skin changes as shown in figure. On investigation, ANA was positive. Which of the following drug would have caused this?
questions.solution:
Drug induced SLE

Adverse effects of Hydralazine are frequent and mainly due to vasodilatation.

  • Facial flushing, conjunctival injection, throbbing headache, dizziness, palpitation, nasal stuffiness, fluid retention, edema, CHF.
  • Angina and MI may be precipitated in patients with coronary artery disease.
  • Postural hypotension is not prominent because of little action on veins.
  • Paresthesias, tremor, muscle cramps, rarely peripheral neuritis. Gastrointestinal disturbances are frequent.
  • Lupus erythematosus or rheumatoid arthritis like symptoms develop on prolonged use of doses above 100 mg/day. This is more common in women and in slow acetylators.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 613

questions.text: A 27 yr male, on treatment with lithium, visited OPD and complaints of decreased libido. Which of the following drugs should not be administered for this patient?
questions.solution:
Aspirin (240 mg - administered daily), and PDE-V inhibitors (Sildenafil) can be administered for treating ED among lithium patients.

Though Indomethacin is effective, it also increases reabsorption of lithium from PCT causing drug accumulation leading onto toxicity symptoms, so its avoided.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 477

choices.text: HCT can be used as second line therapy for lithium induced polyuria
Modafinil used for cognitive impairment due to lithium
Lithium induced severe acne warrants dose reduction/change in therapy
Drug discontinuation in case of lithium induced hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is True regarding management of a patient on adverse effect due to lithium?
questions.solution:
Lithium induced polyuria: First line - Amiloride, second line - HCT (But dose of lithium must be reduced to 1/3rd to prevent drug accumulation)

Lithium induced cognitive impairment - Modafinil / Armodafinil

Lithium induced acne - Decrease dose (If severe, change therapy)

Lithium induced hypothyroidism - No need for dose reduction, TSH levels monitored every 6-12 months)

Before initiation of lithium - Baseline, Thyroid function test and Renal function test must be done.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 644

choices.text: Carbamazepine is more effective than lithium in treating rapid cyclers
TDM must be done for valproate for earlier detection of hepatotoxicity.
Lamotrigene is effective in treating mania episodes more than depressive episodes
Acetazolamide not administered with lithium owing to propensity to toxicity of lithium

questions.text: True statement regarding management of bipolar/mania/depression:
questions.solution:
• TDM need not be done for valproate use, but, baseline and periodic CBC, LFT AND BMI are must be done.
  • Lamotrigine more effective in treating depression than mania
  • Acetazolamide and osmotic diuretics tend to increase excretion of lithium, which leads to decrease in efficacy of lithium when co administered.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 478

questions.text: A 38 yr old male, a PLHIV, was put under highly active anti-retroviral therapy. After few years of regular treatment, the patient came for follow up and complained of bone pain. X-ray was advised which came back as shown in the figure. Which of the following drugs would have been the cause of it?
questions.solution:
Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate is associated with severe nephrotoxicity and demineralization of bone (Osteopenia), which is visible in this X-ray as increased translucency in bone matrix.

Both nephrotoxicity and bone demineralization is less common with Tenofovir alafenamide.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 855

questions.text:

1.Abacavir a.Lactic acidosis
2.Nevirapine b.HS reactions
3.Atazanavir c.Hyperbilirubinemia
4.Stavudine d.Fatal hepatitis
questions.solution:
Abacavir→ HS reactions (HLA B 5701)→ Stop therapy

Nevirapine→ Fatal hepatitis→ More hepatitis if started in patients with more CD4 count

Atazanavir→ Asymptomatic reversible unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Stavudine→ Maximum lactic acidosis among all ARV drugs (Due to mitochondrial toxicity)

questions.text: Occurrence of rash is common with the use of NNRTIs. The following NNRTI is associated with least risk of rash
questions.solution:
Rilpivirine has a lesser incidence (<5%) of rash than any other NNRTIs.

Efavirenz (27%), nevirapine (16%) and delavirdine (18-36%) have higher incidence of rash.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1253

questions.text: A 34 yr old female, came to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, dizziness, blue lips, difficulty in breathing and swallowing past 2 days. History reveals she has been given an injection in her forehead and cheek and was said to produce 'rejuvenation' in her skin and appearance before 4 days. Her respiratory rate and heart rate were found to be higher. Which of the following drugs could be used as a treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of botulism following large (or multiple) injections of botulinum toxin.

Symptoms include:

Mild botulism: Dizziness, headache, fatigue, blepharoptosis, blurred vision

Moderate botulism: All above said symptoms and dysphagia (Need to adopt nasal feeding)

Severe botulism: Tachypnoea, Respiratory failure (requires mechanical ventilation)

This patient is a case of severe botulism, which warrants immediate administration of Botulinum anti-toxin serum 10,000 IU via intra-muscular injection, once every 12 hours (Patients with negative skin test)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 110-111

questions.text: Nitrergic nerves are responsible for which of the following functions of parasympathetic system?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitters at some parasympathetic sites is Nitric oxide which are called as Nitrergic neurons. The release of nitric oxide has been put forth as one of the mechanisms for vasodilation due to cholinergic stimulation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 113-114

questions.text: Optimum medium mass aerodynamic diameter of drug particles to be used as treatment of a patient with bronchial asthma is:
questions.solution:
Much lesser diameters (especially ciclesonide) allows it for more alveolar deposition and thus is likely to increase absorption from lungs into general circulation which might predispose to more systemic side effects.

  2. Adenosine receptor antagonism

  5. Reduction in Bcl-2 (apoptotic protein)
  6. Histone deacetylase activation

choices.text: Consider admitting the patient and administer aminophylline IV
Consider administering ICS with long acting beta 2 agonist (Preferably Formoterol)
Consider administering high dose of inhaled corticosteroids
Check her inhaler technique and persistent allergen exposure.

questions.text: A 23 yr old female patient, diagnosed as asthmatic, was started on inhaled low dose corticosteroids. The patient reports back after 2 months that her symptoms were not subsided, and her exacerbations were not decreased. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
For patients with persistent symptoms and/or exacerbations despite low dose ICS, consider step up, but first check for common problems such as inhaler technique, adherence, persistent allergen exposure and co-morbidities.

Preferred step up Combine low dose ICS and long acting beta 2 agonists.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 252-253

choices.text: Could not breath due to pelvic trauma
Respiratory depression and CO2 retention due to opioid use
Respiratory center depression due to CNS lesion

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with head injury and pelvic fracture and the CT scan suggests raised intracranial tension. Patient was given morphine and the respiratory difficulty followed. What is the most likely cause of respiratory problems?
questions.solution:
Head injury: morphine is contraindicated in patients with head injury. Reasons are-

  • By retaining CO2, it increases intracranial tension which will add to that caused by head injury itself.
  • Even therapeutic doses can cause marked respiratory depression in these patients.
  • Vomiting, miosis and altered mentation produced by morphine interfere with assessment of progress in head injury cases.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 503

questions.text:
Read the following statements regarding the use of given drugs and chose the correct option?
1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary edema
2. Indomethacin can be used in treatment of headache
3. Aspirin is used in treatment of dyspepsia
4. Pethidine can be used in treatment of biliary colic
questions.solution:
Morphine in Acute left ventricular failure/acute pulmonary edema

Morphine injected i.v. affords dramatic relief by-

(a) Reducing preload on heart due to vasodilatation and peripheral pooling of blood.

(b) Tending to shift blood from pulmonary to systemic circuit; relieves pulmonary congestion and edema.

(c) Allaying air hunger and dyspnoea by depressing respiratory centre.

(d) Cutting down sympathetic stimulation by calming the patient, thereby reduces cardiac work.

Pethidine possess anticholinergic activity (can result in tachycardia).These drugs are therefore C/I in MI. Because of anticholinergic properties, these are relatively safer in biliary colic as compared to other agents.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 503-507

questions.text:
A patient presented with absence seizures. Which of the following drugs are useful for this patient?
1. Carbamazepine
2. Ethosuximide
3. Gabapentin
4. Valproate
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 449

questions.text: Which of the following drug should be avoided in a patient on rosuvastatin therapy?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Statins

Gastrointestinal complaints and headache are usually mild. Rashes and sleep disturbances are uncommon.

Rise in serum transaminase can occur, but liver damage is infrequent. Monitoring of liver function is recommended.

Muscle aches are the commonest (10%) side effect. Rise in CPK levels occurs infrequently.

Myopathy is the only serious reaction, but is rare (< 1 per 1000). Few fatalities due to rhabdomyolysis are on record. Myopathy and liver injury is more common when nicotinic acid/ gemfibrozil or CYP3A4 inhibitor-ketoconazole/erythromycin/ cyclosporine/HIV protease inhibitor is given concurrently.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 686

questions.text: Which of the following drug can cause the side-effect given in the picture?
questions.solution:
ADRs of Bleomycin

Mucocutaneous toxicity and pulmonary fibrosis which can be life threatening, but minimal myelosuppression are the special features.

Allergic and hypotensive reaction can occur after bleomycin injection.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 927

questions.text: The following are primarily dependent on kidney for excretion except?
questions.solution:
Cis-atracurium does not depend on kidney for excretion.

Cis-atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination - which is spontaneous non-enzymatic degradation. So renal failure doesn't affect the clearance of cis atracurium. Hence it is the agent of choice in renal failure patients. Atracurium also undergo Hofmann elimination and so is an alternative to cis atracurium in renal failure. Steroidal muscle relaxants are predominantly eliminated by ultrafiltration by the glomeruli before urinary excretion. Doxacurium, pancuronium, and pipecuronium are partially excreted by the kidneys, and so the neuromuscular block is prolonged in patients with renal failure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 32-380

questions.text: Calcium sensitizer agent indicated in management of decompensated congested cardiac failure is.
questions.solution:
Levosimendan is a calcium sensitizing agent indicated for patients with acute decompensated congestive cardiac failure. It enhances myocardial contractility without corresponding increase in cardiac myocyte oxygen requirement. It also causes coronary and systemic vasodilation.

questions.text: Therapeutic drug monitoring is not scientific for which of the following agent?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic drug monitoring is not scientific when the agent is a hit and run drug. Ticlopidine is an example of hit and run drug (P2Y12 inhibitor), the action of the drug persists even in the absence of detectable plasma concentration.

Other examples of hit and run drugs include

MGR's PA

M - MAO inhibitors

G - Guanethidine

R - Reserpine

P - Proton pump inhibitors

A - Aspirin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 678

questions.solution:
Buspirone is an anxioselective agent.

It has got no anti convulsant, sedative, hypnotic or muscle relaxant properties like BZD.

Less sedation than BZD's

Delayed onset of action.

MOA:

Full agonist :

Presynaptic 5-HT 1A in dorsal raphe

Partial agonist:

Post synaptic 5-HT 1A in hippocampus and cortex

questions.text: For which of the following agents 'Structured treatment interruption' strategy is not necessary?
questions.solution:
• 'Structured treatment interruption strategy' is giving drug holidays in between treatment schedule.
  • It is done for two indications:
  • To prevent refractoriness in treatment efficacy (Levodopa, Methylphenidate & Dexamphetamine)
  • To prevent toxicity due to drug accumulation (Digoxin & Taxanes)

questions.text: Patient was given an antipsychotic drug and later developed the feature shown in image. Drug used to treat this feature is
questions.solution:
Antimuscarinic drugs currently used in the treatment of PD include trihexyphenidyl and benztropine mesylate, as well as the antihistaminic diphenhydramine hydrochloride, which also interacts at central muscarinic receptors.

The biological basis for the therapeutic actions of muscarinic antagonists is not completely understood. They may act within the neostriatum through the receptors that normally mediate the response to intrinsic cholinergic innervation of this structure, which arises primarily from cholinergic striatal interneurons.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 419-425

Both assertion and reason are independently true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

questions.text:
Assertion: Larger doses of Acyclovir are recommended for treating genital Herpes in HIV
Reason: Severe/frequent recurrence are seen in HIV
questions.solution:
Both assertion and reasons are independently true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

Acyclovir (synthetic purine nucleoside analogue) acts against herpes viruses by disrupting DNA synthesis.

It is particularly useful in immunocompromised patients because these individuals experience both more frequent and severe HSV and VZV infections.

Dose of acyclovir:

  1. Genital herpes in immunocompetent individuals:400 mg TDS
  2. Genital herpes in immunocompromised individuals (Persons with HIV):800 mg TDS

  • Increased VEGF expression

questions.text: Which of the following drugs might have caused the side effect depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
This is osteonecrosis of jaw duw to zolendronic acid

Zoledronate

This parenteral highly potent 3rd generation BPN is indicated for hypercalcaemia, bony metastasis, osteolytic lesions, and Paget's disease.

Osteoclastic activity is markedly suppressed and an additional antitumour effect may be exerted by interference with mevalonate pathway

Flu-like symptoms due to cytokine release attend the i.v. infusion.

Nausea, vomiting, bodyache and dizziness are also common. Renal toxicity has been encountered. Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a rare complication of i.v. high dose BPN therapy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 371

questions.text: Order of vasodilation for nitrates:
questions.solution:
Veins express greater amount of mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase, the enzyme that generates NO from GTN, than arteries. This may account for the predominant venodilator action. It has been suggested that preferential dilatation of epicardial conducting arteries over autoregulatory arterioles is also due to differential distribution of nitrate metabolizing enzymes in these vessels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 541-587

questions.text: Which of the following drugs tend to produce this adverse drug reaction?
questions.solution:
SGLT-2 inhibitors. This is a case of fournier's gangrene, recently it has been accredited to SGLT-2 inhibitors.

questions.text: According to Vaughan - Williams - Singh classification of anti-arrhythmic, Identify the segment of action potential most affected by Ibutilide from the following illustration (Marked in roman letters I,II,III and IV)
questions.solution:
Ibutilide is a class III anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks outward K+ channels during phase 3 of action potential. It affects duration of action potential without affecting phase 0 depolarization or resting membrane potential.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 579

choices.text: It decreases intracellular sodium and increases intracellular potassium
It decreases stroke volume and cardiac output
It increases vagal activity and decreases sympathetic tone

questions.text: A 76-year-old man has suffered from atrial fibrillation for many years. This condition has been under good control with amiodarone and diltiazem until recently, when he started experiencing palpitations and came back to see you. You decide to start the patient on digoxin therapy. How does this medication work?
questions.solution:
Digoxin, a cardiac glycoside, increases vagal activity, resulting in inhibition of the sinoatrial (SA) node and delayed conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. It also decreases sympathetic tone. Cardiac glycosides increase intracellular sodium while decreasing intracellular potassium; increase intracellular calcium; and increase stroke volume and therefore cardiac output. Cardiac glycosides enhance elimination of sodium and water.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 557

choices.text: Dizziness due to reduced cardiac force of contraction

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of severe chest pain when he walks uphill to his home in cold weather. The pain disappears when he rests. After evaluation and discussion of treatment options, a decision is made to treat him with nitroglycerin. In advising the patient about the adverse effects he may notice, you point out that nitroglycerin in moderate doses often produces certain symptoms. Which of the following effects might occur due to the mechanism listed?
questions.solution:
The nitrates relax many types of smooth muscle, but the effect on motility in the colon is insignificant. Nitroglycerin causes hypotension as a result of arterial and venous dilation. Dilation of arteries in the meninges has no effect on central nervous system function but does cause headache.

Adverse effects of GTNs

These are mostly due to vasodilatation.

  • Fullness in head, throbbing headache; some degree of tolerance develops on continued use.
  • Flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting; these are due to postural hypotension, and are mitigated by lying down. Standing still and alcohol accentuate these symptoms.
  • Methemoglobinemia is not noticeable with clinically used doses; but can further reduce O2 carrying capacity of blood in severe anaemia. Rashes are rare

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 587-588

questions.text:
A drug was tested in the electrophysiology laboratory to determine its effects on the cardiac action potential in normal ventricular cells. The results are shown in the diagram.


Which of the following agent does this drug most resemble?
questions.solution:
The drug effect shown in the diagram includes slowing of the upstroke of the AP but no significant change in repolarization or AP duration. This is most typical of group 1C drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 576

choices.text: Product of Vd and first order rate constant
Area under the blood concentration Vs Time plot

questions.text: Which of the following pharmacokinetic values most reliably reflects the total amount of drug reaching the systemic target after oral administration?
questions.solution:
Bioavailability is determines by AUC of Cp Vs Time plot

Bioavailability explains the fraction of administered drug dose that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form.

Vd and Total body clearance (Vd X first order rate constant) are important in determining the amount of drug that reaches the target tissue

Only AUC reflects absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion factors. That is why it is the most reliable and popular method of evaluating bioavailability

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 22
